awd_titl_txt: Leveraging the AAU Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative to understand and advance the institutionalization of STEM teaching & learning reforms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the institutional transformation processes initiated through the Association of American Universities (AAU) Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative -- a comprehensive change initiative launched in 2011 with funding from the Helmsley Charitable Trust. This is an ambitious project, which seeks to increase the importance of undergraduate STEM education in the nation's top research universities by promoting the implementation of a more systemic view of educational reform. This earlier project initiated change within eight university participants that were selected from a larger pool of AAU applicants to receive seed grants of $500K from AAU. The current project is guided by AAU's "Framework for Systemic Change in Undergraduate STEM Teaching and Learning," developed from leading theories and research on institutional change. That Framework identifies a set of key institutional elements that need to be addressed in order to bring about sustainable change, emphasizing the separate roles of senior university administrators (the top-down component), individual faculty (the bottom-up component), sub academic units in the form of departments and colleges (a middle-out component), and the professional disciplines. The project will document the intricacies of reform within each of the eight universities, producing a set of eight case studies.  

The intellectual merit of the project lies in going beyond the initial phase of implementing the reforms to asking the questions about what factors at the institutional level facilitated the launch, acceptance, success, spread and impact of the reforms. Newer interview questions will be piggy-backed onto the existing time frames for the follow-up inquires in year 4 of the original AAU project's time frame (2016) and additional entities and individuals with the universities will be the focus of the newer investigations. Using the combined data, the PI team expects that newer information about factors important to reform, and the relative importance, priority, or sequence of the factors, to emerge. There is significant value in understanding the complex processes underlying progress at partner institutions in the Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative. Identifying cross-cutting trends (as opposed to institution-specific factors) would be especially valuable. The team also seeks to develop a generalizable, research-based snapshot of successful institutional reform.

por.por_cntn:
The Leveraging the AAU Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative to Understand and Advance the Institutionalization of STEM Teaching & Learning Reforms (NSF IUSE #1625532) project aimed to examine the institutional ecosystem in which innovations to undergraduate STEM education take place at research universities. This project is part of the Association of American Universities (AAU) Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative, which was launched in September 2011, and seeks to improve the quality of undergraduate STEM education by fostering inclusive, evidence-based teaching and learning practices in STEM departments at research universities.

In 2017, AAU launched the Leveraging Study with a team of four researchers. The goal of the study was to take a more nuanced look at how individual institutions were implementing the cross-cutting strategies previously identified in the Progress Toward Achieving Systemic Change: A Five-Year Status Report on the AAU Undergraduate STEM Education Initiative. We wanted to better understand what in an institutional ecosystem most influences the successful implementation and spread of STEM educational reform strategies.

Our overarching finding across the eight universities we studied is that successful implementation and expansion of improvement strategies as well as the alignment of various educational reform projects are dependent first and foremost on the academic department and secondarily by other institutional actors and policies. The academic department is the critical unit for improving teaching and learning in undergraduate STEM education. In addition, key institutional contextual elements influence the values, behaviors, and actions of departments, and in turn, of faculty practices related to teaching and learning. The unique interplay of the department and institutional contextual elements on an individual campus ultimately shapes efforts to improve undergraduate STEM education.

The Academic Department: Central in the Institutional Ecosystem of Undergraduate STEM Education Reform report details the academic department, identifying department-level factors that influence teaching practices and reform efforts and explores eight contextual elements beyond the department - at the institutional level - that influence the department and shape how undergraduate education reforms are adopted.

1      Institutional History & Identity. The historical and aspired identity of leading research universities relative to the importance placed on undergraduate education.

2      Organizational Structure. The extent to which institutions are centralized or decentralized and the impact of varied organizational structures on academic departments.

3      Financial Resources. The effect of funding and allocations for teaching/learning, especially for instructional approaches used in foundational, introductory STEM courses.

4      Faculty Rewards. The location of power and influence in promotion, tenure, and merit decisions, which reflects how faculty members are valued, recognized, and rewarded for teaching contributions.

5      Leadership. The degree of leadership stability and the ways in which commitment of academic and faculty leaders to undergraduate education can influence reform efforts.

6      Undergraduate Student Trends. The influence of demographic trends in enrollment demand and responses to diversity, equity, and inclusion in terms of access and persistence to graduation.

7      Teaching & Learning Structures: Campus-Wide and STEM-Specific. The relationships, coordination, and cooperation among university-wide teaching and learning support structures, college-level STEM centers, and STEM academic departments.

8      Academic Student Supports. The intentionality of student academic supports loosely coupled with, or stand-alone from academic departments, and how these activities influence undergraduate teaching and learning.

To successfully implement, spread, and align various education reforms as well as sustain effective improvement strategies, it is critical to 1) understand and engage the academic department, and 2) recognize the institutional contextual elements that influence, shape, and impact department actions and decision making. Best outcomes occur when the goals of the department and the institution are congruent, and the department and institutional infrastructures work in partnership.
